## The Tech Buzz

### Key Highlights
- A webinar for Real Estate Agents on an alternative to Zillow's Premier Agent starts in 15 minutes.
- Real Intent offers an up to 90% more affordable solution to identify motivated sellers and buyers.
- Agents can leverage advanced technologies to gain a competitive edge in their market.
- The webinar is expected to run for ~30 minutes and will cover real-world examples of successful agents using Real Intent.

### Detailed Points
- The webinar is specifically designed for Real Estate Agents and Brokerages.
- Real Intent uses intent data to identify motivated sellers and buyers at the optimal time.
- The data and technology used by Real Intent were previously only available to large enterprises.
- Agents can learn how to effectively use intent data to find motivated sellers and buyers.
- Examples of successful agents using Real Intent include:
  * One agent increased seller meetings 2 fold and listed 2 properties in the first month.
  * An agent got a listing in their free trial week.
  * An agent secured two more zip codes after experiencing success.
  * A brokerage secured an entire county.
- Real Intent is currently working with 1 broker or agent per zip code.
- Agents can check zip code availability and register for the webinar.
- Real Intent integrates with Follow Up Boss or KVCore, allowing for automatic import of real intent leads with insights and AI magic.

## TAAFT - There's An AI For That

### Key Highlights
- OpenAI's Sora Android app reached 470,000 installs on its first day, surpassing iOS launch metrics.
- Google's Nested Learning tackles AI's forgetting problem by redesigning memory across tasks.
- 2025's Word of the Year is "vibe coding," according to Collins Dictionary.
- Project New Depths enables 3D photo editing with gaussian splats, using millions of tiny 3D elements instead of pixels.

### Detailed Points
- The newsletter covered various AI developments, including OpenAI's Sora Android app, which reached 470,000 installs on its first day, beating iOS launch metrics.
- Google's Nested Learning addresses AI's forgetting problem by redesigning how models handle memory across tasks.
- Collins Dictionary chose "vibe coding" as 2025's Word of the Year, alongside runners-up like "aura farming" and "broligarchy."
- Project New Depths enables 3D photo editing with gaussian splats, using millions of tiny 3D elements instead of pixels.
- The newsletter also featured AI tools such as Token Vault, Tunee, FineVoice, Ping, Keak, Generor, illustration.app, CoverDesignAI, Product Lab, and Jovu.
- Additionally, the newsletter covered the story of a billionaire who shared his advice for young people, emphasizing the importance of hard work and dedication.
- The newsletter also mentioned the launch of Nightfall AI in 2019, which used machine learning to identify credentials, API keys, and personal information in real-time.

newsletters.summary:
## Medium Daily Digest

### Key Highlights
- An article by Alberto Romero titled "You Have No Idea How Screwed OpenAI Is" provides an exhaustive overview of the situation.
- Alpha Iterations published a practical guide to building Agentic RAG using LangGraph.
- Various other articles on AI, machine learning, data science, and related topics were featured in the newsletter.

### Detailed Points
- Alberto Romero's article "You Have No Idea How Screwed OpenAI Is" provides a detailed analysis of OpenAI's current situation, highlighting the challenges and difficulties the company is facing.
- Alpha Iterations' article "Build Agentic RAG using LangGraph" offers a step-by-step guide on how to build Agentic RAG with complete coverage of all necessary steps.
- Other articles featured in the newsletter include "11 Adult Jokes So Funny You'll Be Wiping Away Tears" by Lanquaye George K., "Finding Clients with Expensive Problems: A Practical Guide to Identifying High-Value Prospects" by Chris Dunlop, and "Building a Training Architecture for Self-Improving AI Agents" by Fareed Khan.
- Additionally, there are articles on UX design, data science, machine learning, and software development, including "When AI Agents meet User Experience" by Sneha, "14 logic-driven UI design tips to improve any interface" by Adham Dannaway, and "Forget JSON â€” These 4 Data Formats Made My APIs 5Ã— Faster" by The CS Engineer.
- There are also articles on the intersection of technology and society, such as "We Replaced You With AI (Donâ€™t Ask About the ROI)" by Cat S Guan and "5 Signs of an Inexperienced, Self-Taught Machine Learning Engineer" by Marina Wyss - Gratitude Driven.
- The newsletter also includes articles on personal development, such as "I Used to Be a Quiet Software Developer" by Jeffrey Bakker, and "The 10 Weirdest, Most Brilliant Algorithms Ever Devised and What They Actually Do" by Paolo Perrone.
- Finally, there is an article on the relationship between climate and economic development, titled "Why Warm Countries Are Poorer" by Tomas Pueyo.

newsletters.subject: Nano-Banana vs Pico-Banana to Google going into Space!
newsletters.summary:
## Hello, World!

### Key Highlights
- Google's Nano-Banana vs Apple's Pico-Banana, a competition between two large-scale datasets for text-guided image editing.
- Google's Project Suncatcher research, a moonshot project to deploy solar-powered satellite constellations in space for AI workloads.
- OpenAI's IndQA, a new benchmark designed to test AI models' understanding of Indian culture, languages, and context.
- Proton Mail, a secure email service that keeps newsletters organized without tracking or filtering tricks.

### Detailed Points
- Google and Apple have released large-scale datasets for text-guided image editing: Nano-Banana and Pico-Banana, respectively.
- Google's Project Suncatcher research aims to deploy solar-powered satellite constellations in space to run AI workloads using Google-built TPUs.
- OpenAI has launched IndQA, a benchmark designed to test AI models' understanding of Indian culture, languages, and context across 2,278 questions in 12 languages and 10 domains.
- Proton Mail is a secure email service that keeps newsletters organized without tracking or filtering tricks, providing a better inbox for newsletter lovers and information seekers.
- The newsletter also mentions the launch of several tools and platforms, including Semantic Kernel, an open-source framework by Microsoft, and xTiles, a visual board/app for developers.
- The newsletter also covers job openings in various companies, including Java Development Lead at Endava, Senior Staff Engineer at Salesforce PQO, Senior Full Stack Engineer at Celonis, and Senior Data Engineer at Postman.
- Other important points include the launch of MigrationMiner, a research-grade tool for detecting and tracking library migrations, and Rich, a Python library for beautifying logs, terminals, tables, and CLI output.

newsletters.subject: Beyond Tech: Your Weekend Upgrade
newsletters.summary:
## The Tech Buzz

### Key Highlights
- **Tesla Flying Car**: Elon Musk hints at a potential flying car project, suggesting it may be unveiled soon.
- **USA Digital Passports on Apple Wallet**: Apple plans to introduce digital passports for US citizens, allowing them to store their ID documents in the Wallet app.
- **AI Gaming Board**: A new AI-powered gaming board is set to revolutionize the gaming industry.
- **PayPal on ChatGPT**: PayPal integrates with ChatGPT, enabling users to send and receive payments within the chatbot.
- **Gemini Voice Assistant**: Google's Gemini voice assistant is set to rival Amazon's Alexa and Apple's Siri.
- **Alibabaâ€™s $660 Quark AI Glasses**: Alibaba unveils its Quark AI glasses, priced at $660, with advanced AI-powered features.

### Detailed Points
- **USA Digital Passports on Apple Wallet**: Apple plans to introduce digital passports for US citizens, allowing them to store their ID documents in the Wallet app. This move aims to enhance convenience and security for travelers.
- **Tesla Flying Car**: Elon Musk hints at a potential flying car project, suggesting it may be unveiled soon. This development could revolutionize transportation and transform the automotive industry.
- **AI Gaming Board**: A new AI-powered gaming board is set to revolutionize the gaming industry. The board uses AI to enhance gameplay, providing a more immersive experience for players.
- **PayPal on ChatGPT**: PayPal integrates with ChatGPT, enabling users to send and receive payments within the chatbot. This integration aims to simplify transactions and enhance user experience.
- **Gemini Voice Assistant**: Google's Gemini voice assistant is set to rival Amazon's Alexa and Apple's Siri. Gemini boasts advanced AI-powered features, including improved speech recognition and natural language processing.
- **Alibabaâ€™s $660 Quark AI Glasses**: Alibaba unveils its Quark AI glasses, priced at $660, with advanced AI-powered features. The glasses include augmented reality capabilities, voice assistants, and health monitoring.
- **Sub-$1k MacBook**: Apple plans to launch a sub-$1,000 MacBook with iPhone A-series chips, targeting budget-conscious consumers.
- **Locket's Rollcall**: Locket's Rollcall feature, using Apple's Live Activities, has driven over a million shares in a week, becoming a primary social tool for Gen Alpha.
- **WhatsApp on Apple Watch**: Meta introduces a dedicated WhatsApp app for Apple Watch Series 4 and later, enabling users to read, write, and send messages.
- **Perplexity Partners with Getty**: Perplexity secures a multi-year deal with Getty Images to incorporate their images in its AI tools, addressing content issues and enhancing user experience.
- **xMEMS AI Loudspeakers**: xMEMS Labs secures $21M to enhance piezoMEMS technologies, producing advanced loudspeakers and cooling chips for AI-enabled devices.
- **AI Singer Xania Monet**: Xania Monet becomes the first AI-generated singer to chart on Billboard, marking a historic milestone in the music sector.
- **Disney and Epic Games Partnership**: Disney invests $1.5B in Epic Games to launch a Disneyland Game Rush within Fortnite, merging branded experiences with gaming.
- **Grand Egyptian Museum Opens**: The Grand Egyptian Museum opens with 100,000 artifacts, targeting 5 million annual visitors to boost tourism.
- **Ripple Secures $500M**: Ripple secures $500M at a $40B valuation, transitioning from cross-border payments to a crypto banking platform.
- **Tesla's AI Time Machine**: Explore a speculative 3D video on Nikola Tesla's imagined invention of AI in 1900, projecting accelerated tech evolution.
- **Dynamic Dark Energy**: New studies propose that dark energy may be dynamic and evolving, challenging the traditional view of a constant force.
- **SpaceX's AI Ambitions**: SpaceX's fully reusable Starship is crucial for launching large-scale AI data centers in space, aiming for sub-$80M launch costs.
- **Hippocratic AI Healthcare Boom**: Hippocratic AI secures $126MB valuation, led by Avenir Growth, to expand AI-driven healthcare and address labor and patient access challenges.

newsletters.subject: Bridging text and crystal structures: literature driven contrastive learning for materials science
newsletters.summary:
## JournalClub.io Newsletter

### Key Highlights
- Researchers have developed a new system, CLaSP (Contrastive Language-Structure Pre-training), to bridge text and crystal structures in materials science, enabling the connection of scientific literature with crystal structures.
- CLaSP uses contrastive learning to pair crystal structures with the titles and abstracts of papers that reported them, resulting in a shared embedding space where similar words and materials line up.
- The system has been trained on over 400,000 crystal structures from the Crystallography Open Database and evaluated on a keyword-based retrieval task, showing promising results.

### Detailed Points
- CLaSP aims to solve the representation problem in materials science by learning a general representation of materials that can capture both structural and functional similarities.
- The system uses two encoders: a graph neural network for crystal structures and a SciBERT encoder for text, which produce vectors of the same dimensionality, allowing for direct comparison between structures and text.
- CLaSP's loss function is a large margin cosine loss, which enforces a gap between the positive pair similarity and the negative pair similarities.
- The system has been evaluated on a keyword-based retrieval task, where it showed promising results, with a mean score of 0.78 across six keywords after fine-tuning.
- CLaSP has been compared to an existing crystal embedding method called CMML, which showed weaker performance, highlighting the importance of language supervision in materials science.
- The system has clear limitations around dataset bias and noisy supervision, but represents a real step forward in making materials databases more intuitive and searchable.

### Important Links
- **Watch or Listen to the Episode**: [https://journalclub.io/episodes/bridging-text-and-crystal-structures-literature-driven-contrastive-learning-for-materials-science?token=X43jfr567jW9Rwwpn3YX4YoK1YdHfU0gvDSM6F32d0KO5BypI8](https://journalclub.io/episodes/bridging-text-and-crystal-structures-literature-driven-contrastive-learning-for-materials-science?token=X43jfr567jW9Rwwpn3YX4YoK1YdHfU0gvDSM6F32d0KO5BypI8)

Bridging text and crystal structures: literature driven contrastive learning for materials science   

You're part of a team that is hunting for a new superconductor. A material that is easy to synthesize, easy to stabilize, and can be used to carry current without resistance or enable next-generation electronics. Easier said than done. The hunt for such a structure (or in this case, crystal) can take weeks or months: not just in the lab, but in the literature. Every lead begins with a paper, and every paper references another. You find yourself combing through thousands of entries across databases and journals, trying to piece together which compounds have been tried, which ones worked, and which ones didnâ€™t. Itâ€™s slow, repetitive detective work: scanning titles, abstracts, and datasets for clues about superconductivity.

newsletters.subject: ChatGPT Atlas is here - we tried it
newsletters.summary:
## Mindstream

### Key Highlights
- ChatGPT Atlas is now available, a new browser that integrates AI to enhance browsing experience
- Shaan Puri shares 5 AI business models making $100M+ right now
- A tool of the week is introduced: Copyter, an AI SEO writer that creates structured articles

### Detailed Points
- **ChatGPT Atlas**: A new browser that combines browsing with AI capabilities. It's currently available on macOS, and users can download it from the ChatGPT dashboard.
  - Syncs bookmarks, passwords, and browsing history from Chrome or Safari
  - Features a sidebar assistant that provides information and insights on any webpage
  - Allows users to ask ChatGPT questions directly in the browser
  - Offers browser memories to help users find old searches
  - Has a custom home page that adapts to the user's behavior
- **Shaan Puri's AI Business Models**: Shaan Puri shares 5 AI business models that are making $100M+ right now, including:
  - Gaining creative superpowers like music, word art, and logos
  - Selling defense against AI (fraud/deepfake detection)
  - Employing AI coaches that never slack or sleep
  - Launching a marketing agency (solving shriveling industries)
- **Copyter**: A tool of the week that is an AI SEO writer that creates structured, search-ready articles in 37+ languages.
